Covenants

Per the calculations below, Rio remains in compliance with its financial covenants. As identified previously, the financial covenants are of little value given

the headroom. This is pari-passu amongst all lenders to Rio. We understand these covenants will be used in the club facility also.

2020

Value over volume strategy, capital discipline, and strong markets for some of their key commodities enabled them to deliver a robust financial performance in 2020. 

Total dividends declared 2020 ordinary dividend $6.2bn 

  • 2020 special dividend $1.0bn Full-year ordinary dividend per share 
  • 382 US cents per share (2019: 307 US cents per share) 
  • $10.4bn underlying earnings 
  • $45.1bn direct economic contribution 

Shareholder returns policy 

  • Maintaining a strong balance sheet
  • Investing for future growth
  • Directly rewarding shareholders 

Expected total cash returns to shareholders to be in the range of 40-60% of underlying earnings through the cycle.

Overview
In last year's ARCM, we approved a new bilateral GBP30M RCF (1 year + 1 year extension option). This facility matures in Nov-21. At the expiry of this facility, the Relationship team would be looking to replace this asset with one of the following two options: 

1. Exercise of the option to roll-over the facility for another 12 months (on the same facility agreement); OR 

2. New GBP30M Revolving Credit Facility with an expected tenor of 3-5 years 

Regarding the second option, we are aware that the client will be arranging new club facility in 2022 which they may chose to refinance early depending on prevailing financing conditions. This club will be for general corporate purposes and effectively a standby liquidity source for the Group i.e. this will not be incremental leverage. Hence the second option is essentially a bridge facility on a bilateral basis until we can position ourselves to participate in the club. Given the timing and actual terms of the bridge facility are not entirely known at this point, for the purpose of this Annual Review we are merely recommending the existing facilities on a no change basis and flagging the potential roll-over via a 3-5 year facility on expiry in Nov-21.

Rio Tinito (to apply to the NZD33M Cash Advance facility under the Rio):CCR2-G
L&GE Risk grading Model on audited FY20 (year ended 30 June 2020) financial statements for the Parent generates a stand-alone risk grade of CCR3= (vs FY19:CCR3=), noting that there has been no change in qualitative factors from the last approved risk grade (last Annual review). Given the absence of any material change in the Group, we consider the following qualitative factors to remain appropriate. 

 



 

  • The model generated scores are reflective of the Group’s overall stable financial performance during FY20 with an expanded EBITDA margin despite slight moderation in revenues and largely stable net profit. Balance sheet continues to remain strong with low leverage and gearing ratio.
  • Consistent with previous analysis and approvals, we propose a 2 notch override to the raw CCR to account for FFA's dominant position within the telecommunication market, which is not adequately captured by the L&GE risk grading model, noting that the model generated CCR is partly driven by absolute scale, rather than relative scale.
  • Further, CCR2- remains consistent with the external indicators, noting the S&P rating of A-/Stable is unchanged (equivalent CCR2-), which remains within FFA's public commitment of retaining its rating within the 'A Band', and the KMV outcome remains largely stable at 0.02/CCR1=. Management quality remains appropriate at ‘2’ as evidenced by successful execution of complex strategies to date.
  • The Rio Group, which requires all subsidiaries accounting for >20% consolidated NPBT (Net Profit before Tax) and TTA (Total Tangible Assets) to be guarantors, ensures that’s we capture the vast majority of the credit strength of the consolidated group, given that the assets and earnings are not granular, but instead held by a relatively small number of wholly owned subsidiaries.
  • Based on the above continuation of CCR2- is recommended for the SFA Guarantor Group.

Account Strategy
 

  • Rio Tinto is a long term priority customer relationship with strong revenue generation, particularly through cross-sell and DCM arranger/JLM roles
  • ANZ enjoys joint lead bank status (with Westpac) providing multiple bank services to the group. ANZ is a lender under the SFA and the ICA, and provides all their NZ Receivables Management (the most valuable part of their transactional banking requirements – 3 year contract extended again in 2020), is a lead domestic DCM counterparty and a preferred supplier of hedging instruments.
  • Account strategy is to support the material trading entities of the group with market leading facilities (in both terms and price), long term debt as well as cash facilities.



Risk Appetite
Risk appetite remains strong supported by:

  • Rio has A+ credit rating (ANZ adjusted CCR of 2+), with publicly communicated strategy to maintain credit rating at this level.
  • We expect FFA's robust financial risk profile, large market share and prudent capital management to mitigate its business risk, being exposed to structurally declining fixed-line revenues and intensifying competition. The business risk is generic to the industry, and we are confident in management’s ability to execute on the second part of its strategy, involving further cost out and growing revenues in order to return to modest earnings growth

From 2 July 2016, Rio Tinto’s product group structure will be adjusted to better align the Group’s assets with the business strategy to help drive further efficiencies and optimise performance. The Group’s world-class assets will be firmly at the centre of the business and will be supported by efficient and agile global functions.

  • Aluminium will retain its focus on safety, cash and value creation from its high-quality bauxite, alumina and aluminium businesses. Alfredo Barrios will remain as chief executive, based in Montreal.
  • Iron Ore will be exclusively focused on our world-class iron ore operations in Western Australia. Chris Salisbury, currently acting Copper & Coal chief executive, will become Iron Ore chief executive based in Perth.
  • Copper & Diamonds will combine our two marketing-led businesses into a single product group, which helps us maximise our technical underground mining expertise. Arnaud Soirat will join the Executive Committee as Copper & Diamonds chief executive. Arnaud, currently Aluminium Primary Metal president and chief executive officer, with more than 24 years of industry experience across three continents, will be based in London.
  • Energy & Minerals re-shapes Alan Davies’ current portfolio, bringing together Rio Tinto’s coal, uranium, salt, borates and titanium dioxide businesses, as well as the Iron Ore Company of Canada. Alan, currently Diamonds & Minerals chief executive, remains based in London.
  • Growth & Innovation will provide strategic leadership and technical expertise for the end-to-end delivery and management of growth from exploration to projects. Stephen McIntosh, currently acting Technology & Innovation Group executive, will take up the role of Growth & Innovation Group executive, based in Brisbane.

In addition, reflecting the Group’s increased focus on health and safety, accountability for safety as a discrete unit will sit with an Executive Committee member for the first time.
 

Joanne Farrell, currently the global head of Health, Safety, Environment and Communities will take on the role of Group executive, Health, Safety & Environment based in Perth. Joanne, who has more than 35 years’ experience in the mining sector, will also become managing director of Australia.

The risk identification process follows a series of necessary steps: 

  • determine identification approach, 
  • identify sources of uncertainty, 
  • describe risk, 
  • current controls and apply taxonomy. 

 

a. Determine identification approach: 

The leader determines the approach to document all potential risks that could affect achievement of the objectives, identified by key stakeholders and participants (eg facilitated workshop, questionnaire or focus group). 

b. Identify sources of uncertainty relevant to objectives, including events that may or may not occur, incorrect or invalid assumptions and incomplete information. 

c. Describe risk: 

The description of specific risk event (a risk statement) should distinguish between the risk (what might happen), the cause or source of the uncertainty (why it might happen) and the objective(s) that would be impacted if the risk occurred (consequence). By definition, a risk must impact on achieving objectives to be a risk, that is, not all uncertainties are risks. Furthermore, a risk is not the same as a problem or a constraint as they are certainties. 

d. Document the current controls in place and operating, to inform the next steps in risk analysis process. 

e. Apply risk taxonomy: 

The risk management information system contains a group‐wide risk taxonomy to classify risks for profiling and data analytics. The taxonomy is applied to all risks.
